This made the Parrotts much more accurate and destructive than earlier smoothbore cannons that fired round shots. The Parrots were cast iron muzzle-loaders like the smoothbores and could penetrate masonry forts. In the 1890s and early 1900s steel, breech-loading rifles replaced the Parrotts, and concrete-and-earthwork batteries replaced masonry fortifications like Fort Massachusetts.

properties.name: Fort Massachusetts Tour: Stop 6
properties.notes:
Fort Massachusetts Tour: Stop 6 https://www.nps.gov/places/000/fort-massachusetts-tour-stop-6.htm

Cannon Debris

Fort Massachusettes was designed for 37 cannon, but only 17 were mounted during the 1870s. In the early 1900s, many were sold for scrap. Due to their weight, most were broken apart before removal. The debris here, was never removed from the fort. Scattered on top of the pad and on the grass around the pad are large broken pieces of a cannon. 

Feel free to touch these pieces, but please do not sit on anything.

properties.name: Fort Massachusetts Tour: Stop 7
properties.notes:
Fort Massachusetts Tour: Stop 7 https://www.nps.gov/places/000/fort-massachusetts-tour-stop-7.htm

Stair Tower

The round stair tower sits at the end of a brick walk directly across from the entrance to the fort. An arched doorway leads into the tower where a concrete staircase begins at the right and circles counterclockwise up to the top. The three spiral granite staircases were built to provide protection against enemy fire.

properties.name: Fort Massachusetts Tour: Stop 8
properties.notes:
Fort Massachusetts Tour: Stop 8 https://www.nps.gov/places/000/fort-massachusetts-tour-stop-8.htm

 

Hot Shot Furnace



This coal-fired furnace was built to heat cannon balls before firing them at ships. This furnace was never used.

This brick structure sitting in the middle of the fort is about 9 feet square with a large square chimney at the end facing the middle of the parade. Below the chimney is wide opening that tunnels all the way through the structure to a similar opening at the far end. Three iron pipes extend the length of the tunnel, forming a horizontal rack. On the wall are five star-like iron braces held in place by rods that pass through the structure to support the side walls. At lower left on this wall are two smaller openings giving access to the firebox.

Imagine what it was like for soldiers in the blazing sun to heat solid cannonballs in a furnace like this one.

One soldier maintained the coal fire and put up to 60 cannonballs on racks in the furnace. A second removed the heated balls with tongs. A third cleaned them with a rasp, and others carried them in ladles to the guns. 

This furnace was ordered as a kit and installed. Although common to coastal forts, this furnace was never used.

properties.name: Fort Massachusetts Tour: Stop 9
properties.notes:
Fort Massachusetts Tour: Stop 9 https://www.nps.gov/places/000/fort-massachusetts-tour-stop-9.htm

 

Guardrooms



One on either side of the sally port, are rooms created to house soldiers. However, most of the soldiers lived outside the fort.

A narrow opening in the walls allowed the soldiers to fire on enemy forces with rifles. In the rear left corner there is a rack holding long cannon tools with a cannon ball and a smaller shot on the floor at the right.

Feel free to touch this display.

properties.name: Fort Pickens
properties.notes:
Fort Pickens https://www.nps.gov/places/000/fort-pickens.htm

The United States Army built Fort Pickens in the 1800’s to help defend the Gulf Coast from overseas enemies. In 1821, the Third System of coastal forts was extended to include protecting Pensacola Bay and the communities that lined the mainland shore. Pensacola Bay had long been considered important by European powers that sought to colonize North America.

By 1825, legislation was passed to establish a navy yard and depot on the bay. Fortifications were needed to protect the new territory, its resources, and assets.

From Santa Rosa Island, the fort worked with Fort McRee on Perdido Key to guard the entrance to Pensacola Bay. Fort Barrancas and the Spanish Water Battery, staring down from a bluff facing the harbor’s entrance, added more protection. Fort Barrancas and Advanced Redoubt guarded the Pensacola Navy Yard from land attacks.

What many people don't know is that Fort Pickens was built on a bed of violence and cruelty. The Army forced enslaved Black men to build and later repair the fort. This didn't stop Fort Pickens from becoming a destination on the Underground Railroad during the Civil War and after. Freedom-seeking African Americans traveled to the fort to emancipate themselves.

Following the Civil War and after the Apache Wars ended in the 1880’s, the Army concentrated Chiricahua Apache at Fort Pickens. Prisoners of war like Geronimo, a leader and medicine man, labored at the fort for one and a half years. The Chiricahua Apache remained prisoners of war for another 27 years.

However, new technologies made Fort Pickens outdated. The Army continued using the fort until the end of World War II. In the 1890s, the fort supported an underwater minefield. Soldiers kept supplies for Battery Pensacola inside the fort's brick rooms. In the early 1900's, the Army set up a power plant in the fort to create electricity for the base.

Fort Pickens joined the National Park Service's Gulf Islands National Seashore in 1971. Today the fort stands as a monument to military technology and as a memorial to past injustices.

properties.name: Fort Pickens Area
properties.notes:
Fort Pickens Area https://www.nps.gov/places/000/fort-pickens-area.htm

The Fort Pickens Area is located on the western end of Santa Rosa Island and preserves over a century of American coastal defensive structures.

The area features many beach access points to visit the incredible white-sandy beaches and enjoy the blue-green waters of the Gulf of Mexico. Take a hike on one of the many trails, including the Florida National Scenic Trail.

In the historic district, explore the historic fortifications with a ranger or with one of the self-guiding tours. The Fort Pickens Discovery Center offers fun, interactive exhibits for all ages about the history of the site as well as its natural wonders. A bookstore open year round at historic Fort Pickens.

properties.name: Fort Pickens Area Entrance Station
properties.notes:
Fort Pickens Area Entrance Station https://www.nps.gov/places/000/fort-pickens-area-entrance-station.htm

The Fort Pickens Area is located on the western end of Santa Rosa Island and preserves over a century of American coastal defensive structures.

The area features many beach access points to visit the incredible white-sandy beaches and enjoy the blue-green waters of the Gulf of Mexico. Take a hike on one of the many trails, including the Florida National Scenic Trail.

In the historic district, explore the historic fortifications with a ranger or with one of the self-guiding tours. The Fort Pickens Discovery Center offers fun, interactive exhibits for all ages about the history of the site as well as its natural wonders. A bookstore open year round at historic Fort Pickens.

Entrance fees are charged for most of the Florida areas of the national seashore. Passes are good for seven days and can be purchased at the park entrance stations or online. For more frequent visitors, the national seashore offers an annual pass providing 12-months of unlimited entries into all of the park's areas.

Know before you go:
- Dogs are not allowed on the beach or in the fort
- Obey speed limit signs, 25 miles per hour or less
- Do not enter marked off areas on dunes

properties.name: Fort Pickens Area Orientation Kiosk
properties.notes:
Fort Pickens Area Orientation Kiosk https://www.nps.gov/places/000/fort-pickens-area-orientation-kiosk.htm

Stop here for a great photo opp with the Fort Pickens Area Entrance Sign or to learn more about the seashore from the kiosk. 

The Fort Pickens Area Orientation Kiosk is located along Fort Pickens Road just inside the park, but before the entrance station. There are several parallel parking spots at this kiosk.

properties.name: Fort Pickens Bay Trail
properties.notes:
Fort Pickens Bay Trail https://www.nps.gov/places/000/dune-trail.htm The Bay Trail is a 0.15 mile trail beginning at the north side of Fort Pickens Campground Loop E. Visitors may park at overflow parking located directly in front of the trailhead, or walk from their campsite. The Florida National Scenic Trail can be found a few feet to the right.

A gently inclined, sandy slope will bring visitors up over the dunes, past coastal vegetation, and down to the Pensacola Bay. A variety of birds can frequently be seen flying overhead, including bald eagles, ospreys, great blue herons, and more.

Duration: 15-30 minutes

properties.name: Fort Pickens Campground: Loop A
properties.notes:
Fort Pickens Campground: Loop A https://www.nps.gov/places/000/fort-pickens-campground-loop-a.htm

Loop A Fort Pickens Campground is the most popular at the national seashore with 43 total sites to choose from. Live oaks and other trees provide excellent shade over nearly all sites and there is a beach access point directly across the street from the entrance to the campground loop.

The loop is located east of the main campground loops. To the north of the loop is the Blackbird Marsh Trail, a nature trail with interpretive panels. The trail connects to the Florida Trail providing access to the rest of the Fort Pickens Area.

Know Before You Go!

properties.name: Fort Pickens Campground: Loop A Dump Station
properties.notes:
Fort Pickens Campground: Loop A Dump Station https://www.nps.gov/places/000/fort-pickens-campground-loop-a-dump-station.htm

Fort Pickens Campground RV dump stations are for the use of registered campers only. Non-campers must pay a $5 fee at the campground office to use the dump stations.

properties.name: Fort Pickens Campground: Loop A Dumpster
properties.notes:
Fort Pickens Campground: Loop A Dumpster https://www.nps.gov/places/000/fort-pickens-campground-loop-a-dumpster.htm

There are two dumpsters at this location; one is for normal waste, the other is for recycling.

properties.name: Fort Pickens Campground: Loop A Restrooms
properties.notes:
Fort Pickens Campground: Loop A Restrooms https://www.nps.gov/places/000/fort-pickens-campground-loop-a-restrooms.htm

This facility features men's and women's restrooms and showers. Coin-operated laundry machines are available at the Loop C Restroom building.

Facilities for registered campers only.

properties.name: Fort Pickens Campground: Loop B
properties.notes:
Fort Pickens Campground: Loop B https://www.nps.gov/places/000/fort-pickens-campground-loop-b.htm

Loop B is reserved for soft-sided, on the ground tents only. With 13 sites total, each campsite has a grill/fire ring and picnic table. There are no site hook-ups, but there are centralized water stations. Generators are not permitted in this loop.

There is a beach access point directly across the street from the entrance to the campground loop. The Florida Trail runs through the loop providing access to the rest of the Fort Pickens Area including the historic district.

Know Before You Go!

properties.name: Fort Pickens Campground: Loop C
properties.notes:
Fort Pickens Campground: Loop C https://www.nps.gov/places/000/fort-pickens-campground-loop-c.htm

Loop C in the Fort Pickens Campground is one of the larger loops at the national seashore with 60 total sites. The loop is located on the eastern end of the campground. There are limited sites with shade, tree replanting efforts are underway. 

There is a beach access point directly across the street from the entrance of the campground loop. The Florida Trail runs through the campground providing access to the rest of the Fort Pickens Area.

Know Before You Go!

properties.name: Fort Pickens Campground: Loop C Restrooms
properties.notes:
Fort Pickens Campground: Loop C Restrooms https://www.nps.gov/places/000/fort-pickens-campground-loop-c-restrooms.htm

This facility features men's and women's restrooms, showers, and coin-operated laundry machines.

Facilities for registered campers only.

properties.name: Fort Pickens Campground: Loop D
properties.notes:
Fort Pickens Campground: Loop D https://www.nps.gov/places/000/fort-pickens-campground-loop-d.htm

Loop D in the Fort Pickens Campground offers 29 total sites that can accommodate small recreational vehicles (Class-B), pick-up campers, and tents. Each campsite has a grill/fire ring and picnic table. There are no site hook-ups, but there are centralized water stations. Trailers are not permitted in this loop.

There is a beach access point directly across the street from the entrance to the campground loop. The Florida Trail runs through the loop providing access to the rest of the Fort Pickens Area.

Know Before You Go!

properties.name: Fort Pickens Campground: Loop E
properties.notes:
Fort Pickens Campground: Loop E https://www.nps.gov/places/000/fort-pickens-campground-loop-e.htm

Loop E in the Fort Pickens Campground is the largest loop in the national seashore with 66 total sites. Each site has water and electricity hook-ups, grill/fire rings, and picnic tables.

There is a beach access point directly across the street from the campground loop entrance. The Florida Trail runs through the loop providing access to the rest of the Fort Pickens Area.

Know Before You Go!

properties.name: Fort Pickens Campground: Loop E Dumpsters
properties.notes:
Fort Pickens Campground: Loop E Dumpsters https://www.nps.gov/places/000/fort-pickens-campground-loop-e-dumpsters.htm

There are two dumpsters in this location. One for regular camping waste, the other is for recycling only.

properties.name: Fort Pickens Campground: Loop E Restrooms
properties.notes:
Fort Pickens Campground: Loop E Restrooms https://www.nps.gov/places/000/fort-pickens-campground-loop-e-restrooms.htm

This facility features men's and women's restrooms and showers. Coin-operated laundry machines are available at the Loop C Restroom building.

Facilities for registered campers only.

properties.name: Fort Pickens Campground: Loops B & D Restrooms
properties.notes:
Fort Pickens Campground: Loops B & D Restrooms https://www.nps.gov/places/000/fort-pickens-campground-loops-b-d-restrooms.htm

This facility features men's and women's restrooms, showers, and coin-operated laundry machines.

Facilities for registered campers only.

properties.name: Fort Pickens Campground: Loops B-E Dump Station
properties.notes:
Fort Pickens Campground: Loops B-E Dump Station https://www.nps.gov/places/000/fort-pickens-campground-loops-b-e-dump-station.htm

Fort Pickens Campground RV dump stations are for the use of registered campers only. Non-campers must pay a $5 fee at the campground office to use the dump stations.

properties.name: Fort Pickens Dune Trail
properties.notes:
Fort Pickens Dune Trail https://www.nps.gov/places/000/dune-nature-trailhead.htm

The Dune Trail is a 0.15 mile boardwalk trail through primary and secondary dunescape. It is located in the Fort Pickens area, directly south of campground Loop A. Visitors may walk or bike to the trailhead, or park in the lot directly in front. Please stay on the trail and do not walk in the dunes, to preserve our coastal vegetation.

The boardwalk traverses through foredune communities, which are home to many different animal and plant species. Foredunes are created by sand blowing inland from the beach, forming a line that runs adjacent to the coast. Foredunes help shelter plant life from exposure to and create pockets where less salt-tolerant floral communities can form. 

A rest bench is provided along the trail, but no shade will be found on sunny days, so bring water and pack accordingly.

Duration: 15-30 minutes

properties.name: Fort Pickens Fishing Pier
properties.notes:
Fort Pickens Fishing Pier https://www.nps.gov/places/000/fort-pickens-fishing-pier.htm

Known as the most popular place to fish in the Fort Pickens area. The fishing pier stretches out 200 feet into Pensacola Bay. It is a great place to catch fish, view dolphins, or watch the sunset.

The Fort Pickens Area Fishing Pier is a licensed pier. You do not need a license if you are fishing for recreational purposes from a pier that has a valid saltwater pier fishing license. Please abide by Florida state fishing regulations and practice leave no trace.

Fishing Pier Rules:
- Limit two poles or one pole, one cast net per person.

Prohibited:
-  Fishing by bow, spear gun or Hawaiian slings.
- Alcohol, pets, glass, generators, texts, canopies, or any other shelter.

properties.name: Fort Pickens Group Campsite
properties.notes:
Fort Pickens Group Campsite https://www.nps.gov/places/000/fort-pickens-group-campsite.htm

Reserve the Fort Pickens group campsite for access to numerous trails, forts, and Langdon swim beach.

Throughout the year the Fort Pickens group campsite area is reservable for groups with a minimum of ten and maximum of forty people. Only tents are allowed at this location.

The Fort Pickens group campsite is located within the Fort Pickens Area, west of Pensacola Beach.

properties.name: Fort Pickens Jetties
properties.notes:
Fort Pickens Jetties https://www.nps.gov/places/000/fort-pickens-jetties.htm

Known as one of the most popular scuba and snorkeling spots at the national seashore. Located near the western tip of the Fort Pickens Area on the sound side, it is a great place to snorkel, scuba or lauch a kayak. It also provides a great view of the Pensacola Lighthouse and dolphins.

This is a protected wildlife area. Please stay off of the dunes and out of shorebird enclosures. Pets, glass, and driving are not permitted on beach.

properties.name: Fort Pickens Park Store
properties.notes:
Fort Pickens Park Store https://www.nps.gov/places/fort-pickens-park-store.htm The Gulf Islands National Seashore park store is found on the right side of the sally port, or large entrance archway, of Fort Pickens. It is operated by Eastern National, an official non-profit partner of the National Park Service dedicated to supporting our educational mission. 

The park store has a wide range of books, clothing, replica historical items, educational games, posters, and other items available for retail sale. No food is sold, and only bottled water is available. These products complement the interpretive themes you experience when visiting the park. Over the years, funds from bookstore sales have funded special events, signage for trails and exhibits, publications, interpretive programs, research grants, internships, the purchase of historical artifacts, park programs for kids, reenactments, interpretive exhibits, and much more.

The park store is located in Fort Pickens, Florida, or you can purchase Gulf Islands products from the online park store at Americas National Parks.

properties.name: Fort Pickens Tour: Stop 1
properties.notes:
Fort Pickens Tour: Stop 1 https://www.nps.gov/places/000/fort-pickens-tour-stop-1.htm

Sally Port


You are standing inside a covered walkway called a sally port. A sally port served as the main path into and out of a fort like Fort Pickens.To enter Fort Pickens in the early 1800s, soldiers marched across a wooden bridge.

The bridge stretched 180 feet over a dry ditch. When they reached the sally port, soldiers found several sets of heavy wooden doors. Now missing, these wooden doors allowed soldiers to control access to the fort.

The Army changed the sally port in the late 1800s. In 1896, work crews began laying railroad tracks on Santa Rosa Island. Workers used the railroad to move building materials. Soldiers used the railroad to move weapons, ammunition, and supplies around the post.

To help build Battery Pensacola, the Army ran railroad tracks from a dock on Pensacola Bay. The tracks passed through the sally port and ran to the middle of Fort Pickens. Deep, narrow grooves cut into the granite are one trace of the old railroad.

Turn left to begin your self guided tour.

properties.name: Fort Pickens Tour: Stop 10
properties.notes:
Fort Pickens Tour: Stop 10 https://www.nps.gov/places/000/fort-pickens-tour-stop-10.htm

Bastion A

You are entering a bastion through a side door called a postern. A bastion is a projection from the main wall of a fort. It allowed defenders to fire along a fort’s wall. Soldiers called this bastion Bastion A.

Like Bastion E, which you passed through earlier in this self-guided tour, Bastion A has casemates and embrasures for cannon. It also has a countermine with three tunnels and a powder magazine. The interior of this bastion looks much as it did in the 1800s.

properties.name: Fort Pickens Tour: Stop 11
properties.notes:
Fort Pickens Tour: Stop 11 https://www.nps.gov/places/000/fort-pickens-tour-stop-11.htm

Battery Pensacola Tunnel

The Army built Battery Pensacola between 1898–1899. Shortly after construction began, it decided to add a tunnel to the project.

This tunnel extended from the south side of the battery, where you are standing, to the north side. This tunnel allowed soldiers to use the casemates that once existed inside the fort’s south wall.

In the early 1920s, a work crew built a new power station to provide electricity to the battery. They placed the power station in a location that closed the north entrance to the tunnel.

properties.name: Fort Pickens Tour: Stop 12
properties.notes:
Fort Pickens Tour: Stop 12 https://www.nps.gov/places/000/fort-pickens-tour-stop-12.htm

Cisterns

These are the remains of Bastion B’s two cisterns. These cisterns stored rainwater that fell on Fort Pickens. Soldiers used this water to drink, cook, and wash their uniforms.

Two more cisterns were once located in the fort’s northwest bastion, Bastion D. Together, these four cisterns stored 193,392 gallons of water. With this supply, 1,200 soldiers could survive in the fort for up to 161 days.

The Bastion B cisterns sustained damage between 1915–1916. The Bastion D cisterns were destroyed in an accidental explosion in 1899.

Help protect Fort Pickens. Please stay off the walls and do not pick up loose bricks

properties.name: Fort Pickens Tour: Stop 13
properties.notes:
Fort Pickens Tour: Stop 13 https://www.nps.gov/places/000/fort-pickens-tour-stop-13.htm

Reverse Arch

There is a whole substructure supporting Fort Pickens. Hidden underfoot is a web of wooden beams and reverse brick arches.

Enslaved Black laborers broke ground on Fort Pickens in 1829. They began by digging into the island. They then installed a heavy framework of wooden beams called grillage. Using lumber from local Pensacola mills, the laborers installed grillage to create a foundation.

Engineers used arches to support the weight of the fort on this grillage foundation. Overhead arches spread the weight to the piers. The reverse arches distributed the weight across the grillage structure to limit settling.

properties.name: Fort Pickens Tour: Stop 14
properties.notes:
Fort Pickens Tour: Stop 14 https://www.nps.gov/places/000/fort-pickens-tour-stop-14.htm

Tower Bastion

This is Tower Bastion. From the barbette above, soldiers fired cannon over the fort’s wall. Inside the casemates below, defenders fired cannon along the fort’s wall.

From the barbette you can see the Gulf of Mexico, Pensacola Pass, and Pensacola Bay. Here a 15-inch Rodman gun, capable of firing a 450-pound solid shot up to five miles away, stands guard over the Emerald Coast.

Looking south toward the Gulf of Mexico, you can see damaged walls with exposed arches. Engineers demolished these walls between 1915–1916. Upon completion, soldiers at Battery Pensacola had better views of targets. Today, the exposed arches help us understand how the fort was built.

Help protect Fort Pickens. Please stay off the walls and do not pick up loose bricks.

properties.name: Fort Pickens Tour: Stop 15
properties.notes:
Fort Pickens Tour: Stop 15 https://www.nps.gov/places/000/fort-pickens-tour-stop-15.htm

Battery Pensacola

Engineers designed and built an elaborate defense system on Pensacola Bay between 1895–1943. Completed in 1899, Battery Pensacola once played a major role in this system. Four amazing technologies made Battery Pensacola revolutionary.

A newer construction material, reinforced concrete made the structure stronger than Fort Pickens. The concrete was painted black to reduce glare from the intense Florida sun. Newly invented electrical distribution provided the electricity to make loading and firing the battery’s guns easier.

The newly invented telephone allowed soldiers to communicate information more quickly and over greater distances. Steel guns capable of withstanding the extreme forces allowed soldiers to hit targets with deadly precision.

Like Fort Pickens, Battery Pensacola became obsolete. The Army stopped using the battery in 1933 and removed its guns in 1934.Visit Battery Cooper and its 6-inch disappearing gun to see an example of an armed battery on Pensacola Bay.

properties.name: Fort Pickens Tour: Stop 16
properties.notes:
Fort Pickens Tour: Stop 16 https://www.nps.gov/places/000/fort-pickens-tour-stop-16.htm

Bastion D

This damaged pier and arch are the result of an accidental explosion in the late 1800s. The explosion destroyed Bastion D and created this large gap.

In the early morning hours of June 20, 1899, soldiers discovered a fire near the sally port. Here, casemates housed large wooden blocks for moving guns and artillery supplies. The officer in charge, Second Lieutenant Robert H. C. Kelton, 1st US Artillery, led his 60 men in fighting the fire. As the fire spread toward Bastion D, it moved closer to a powder magazine holding 8,000 pounds of explosives. Unable to control the fire, Kelton withdrew his men before the magazine exploded.

The explosion wounded Private Henry Hopgood and killed another, Private Earle F. Welles. Today Private Welles rests across the bay at Barrancas National Cemetery.

The fire's cause remains unknown to this day. Eleven soldiers, including Kelton, were recognized for their “. . . heroic and energetic efforts . . .”

properties.name: Fort Pickens Tour: Stop 2
properties.notes:
Fort Pickens Tour: Stop 2 https://www.nps.gov/places/000/fort-pickens-tour-stop-2.htm

Officer's Quarters


You are inside an officers’ living quarters. An officer used a room like this for sleeping, an office, and sometimes as headquarters. Fort Pickens once had six officers’ quarters in the north wall and seven in the south wall. Most officers’ quarters no longer exist. In 1861, the first year of the Civil War, some of these rooms served as a hospital for Union troops.

At this hospital surgeons and their assistants cared for the sick, wounded, and dying. Those who died in defense of the United States were laid to rest in a temporary cemetery outside the fort.

Later, around 1888, soldiers used rooms like these to house Chiricahua Apache prisoners of war, including Geronimo and his family.

properties.name: Fort Pickens Tour: Stop 3
properties.notes:
Fort Pickens Tour: Stop 3 https://www.nps.gov/places/000/fort-pickens-tour-stop-3.htm

Casemates

The arched rooms around you are casemates. Casemates protected soldiers and cannon. They also supported the upper level, or barbette, of Fort Pickens. Each casemate in the fort had one or two windows, or embrasures. Soldiers fired cannon through these embrasures.

This cannon is a 32-pounder. It sits on top of an oak carriage. The carriage is connected to the brick wall. Look under the embrasure and you will discover an opening. A metal plate, called a tongue, connects the carriage to a metal pin in the wall.

This system locked the cannon to the wall and helped soldiers point their weapon. Look down at the floor and you will find granite blocks, or traverse stones. With iron rails bolted on top, travers stones made rolling cannon from side to side easier. Today you can still see the remains of traverse stones and rails around the fort. Cannon like this 32-pounder made a lot of smoke.

Vents above embrasures allowed the smoke to escape. When a cannon fired, fresh air entered a casemate through a chimney or a diamond-shaped opening in the ceiling.

Help protect Fort Pickens. Do not climb on the cannon.

properties.name: Fort Pickens Tour: Stop 4
properties.notes:
Fort Pickens Tour: Stop 4 https://www.nps.gov/places/000/fort-pickens-tour-stop-4.htm

Mine Casemate

This doorway leads into the first mine casemate at Fort Pickens. Completed in 1894, this room became one of several onshore buildings used by soldiers to operate an underwater minefield. Long ago, the Army considered underwater mines one of the main weapons needed to defend a harbor.

When engineers began updating Pensacola Bay’s defenses in the late 1800s, they made sure to include mines in their plans. A mine casemate was the heart of a controlled mine system.

This area held batteries that powered the mines. It also housed the controls for setting off the mines. From the mine casemate, electrical cables ran underground, entered the bay, and extended to the minefield.

When an officer gave the command, a soldier at the operating panel flipped a switch and detonated a mine. Because of high humidity, engineers built a new mine casemate outside the fort in 1907. This brick building still stands today. The Army eliminated Pensacola Bay’s mine defense system in 1926.

properties.name: Fort Pickens Tour: Stop 5
properties.notes:
Fort Pickens Tour: Stop 5 https://www.nps.gov/places/000/fort-pickens-tour-stop-5.htm

Countermine

Soldiers had many options to defend Fort Pickens. You are outside one of those options called a countermine. Fort Pickens has two countermines. The countermines are on the fort’s landward side and next to powder magazines. Both have three narrow chambers that extend into the wall.

During a battle, soldiers in the fort could move kegs of gun powder from a powder magazine to a chamber. Each chamber could hold 1,027 pounds of gun powder.

When an attacker charged the fort, the defenders would ignite the gun powder and explode a chamber. The explosion would wreck the fort but stop an attack.

properties.name: Fort Pickens Tour: Stop 6
properties.notes:
Fort Pickens Tour: Stop 6 https://www.nps.gov/places/000/fort-pickens-tour-stop-6.htm

Powder Magazine

Engineers designed Fort Pickens to hold 205 cannon. To fire cannon, soldiers needed gun powder. This small doorway opens into the only remaining powder magazine.

Fort Pickens originally had three powder magazines. The magazines were lined with wood to help keep gun powder dry. Anyone who entered a magazine had to remove their shoes or put socks over them to prevent sparks.

This is because the soles of shoes were sometimes attached with nails. Fort Pickens’ three magazines could hold more than 272,000 pounds of powder. This large quantity allowed soldiers to defend the fort during a long siege.

properties.name: Fort Pickens Tour: Stop 7
properties.notes:
Fort Pickens Tour: Stop 7 https://www.nps.gov/places/000/fort-pickens-tour-stop-7.htm

Gallery and Shelf Supports

This covered walkway is a gallery. A gallery protected soldiers and supplies while moving around a fort in a battle. The Army added concrete stalls to the gallery in the late 1800s.

The original use remains unclear. Soldiers may have used these stalls as shelf supports to store equipment. They could have kept equipment here for the underwater minefield. Or they could have used the supports for a fort inside Fort Pickens named Battery Pensacola.

properties.name: Fort Pickens Tour: Stop 8
properties.notes:
Fort Pickens Tour: Stop 8 https://www.nps.gov/places/000/fort-pickens-tour-stop-8.htm

Central Power Station

Engineers had a bright idea in 1903. They decided to install a central power station at Fort Pickens. You are standing in the power station. It provided outdoor and indoor lighting for the military post. The three casemates in front of you were originally meant for cannon.

In 1903, engineers turned these rooms into a central power station. Here they installed one 50-kilowatt Skinner-Willey generator. It also had one 8- and one 10-kilowatt General Electric generators. The station housed three engines, a switchboard, and three storage batteries. To power the generators, engineers built a boiler house outside the power station.

This building housed a 103-horsepower Babcock and Wilcox boiler, a feed pump, and heater. Coal was stored in a casemate near the sally port. By the 1920s, the Army no longer needed the central power station. The equipment was sold, and the boiler house demolished.

Help protect Fort Pickens. Please stay off the walls and do not pick up loose bricks.

properties.name: Fort Pickens Tour: Stop 9
properties.notes:
Fort Pickens Tour: Stop 9 https://www.nps.gov/places/000/fort-pickens-tour-stop-9.htm

Counterscarp, Scarp, and Dry Ditch

You are standing in front of an outer wall called a counterscarp. The counterscarp supports a man-made hill called a glacis.

Like a shield, the counterscarp protected Fort Pickens’ main wall, called the scarp.In the 1800s, the counterscarp and scarp measured about 40 feet tall. Wrapping around Fort Pickens, a dry ditch separated these towering walls.

Attackers who reached the dry ditch would be caught in a deadly crossfire. By the summer of 1915, Army engineers filled the dry ditch to better protect the area from hurricanes. They also spread compost and planted grass to hold and fix the sand and to reduce the glare from the sun.

properties.name: Fort Pickens Tram Service: Stop 1
properties.notes:
Fort Pickens Tram Service: Stop 1 https://www.nps.gov/places/000/fort-pickens-tram-service-stop-1.htm

The Fort Pickens Tram Service provides free access to all visitors on Friday and Saturday to the most popular places in the Fort Pickens Area including the historic fort, the campground, and Langdon Beach.

Stop 1 is located at the Pensacola Bay City Ferry Fort Pickens Departure Point. At this stop there are restrooms, a water filling station, a shaded shelter, and the Mine Storeroom where visitors can purchase ferry boat tickets and beverages.

properties.name: Fort Pickens Tram Service: Stop 2
properties.notes:
Fort Pickens Tram Service: Stop 2 https://www.nps.gov/places/000/fort-pickens-tram-service-stop-2.htm

The Fort Pickens Tram Service provides free access to all visitors on Friday and Saturday to the most popular places in the Fort Pickens Area including the historic fort, the campground, and Langdon Beach.

Stop 1 is located at the Fort Pickens Campground. There is also a beach access point at this stop.

properties.name: Fort Pickens Tram Service: Stop 3
properties.notes:
Fort Pickens Tram Service: Stop 3 https://www.nps.gov/places/000/fort-pickens-tram-service-stop-3.htm

The Fort Pickens Tram Service provides free access to all visitors on Friday and Saturday to the most popular places in the Fort Pickens Area including the historic fort, the campground, and Langdon Beach.

Stop 3 is located at Langdon Beach which features a seasonally lifeguarded swim beach, pavilion, beach showers, and restrooms.

properties.name: Fort Pickens Visitor Center
properties.notes:
Fort Pickens Visitor Center https://www.nps.gov/places/000/fort-pickens-visitor-center.htm

Discover the wonders of Santa Rosa Island inside the Fort Pickens Visitor Center. The miles of sandy quartz beaches provide beach, dune, and forest area habitats for many plants and animals. Historic forts and buildings tell the stories of United States coastal defense.

properties.name: Fort Within a Fort
properties.notes:
Fort Within a Fort https://www.nps.gov/places/000/fort-within-a-fort.htm

Fort Pickens was past its prime. New rifled artillery could penetrate its brick walls. The U.S. Army resuscitated the antiquated brick fort in 1898 with reinforced concrete Battery Pensacola. This fort within a fort had two 12-inch rifles on carriages that could disappear behind the walls after firing 1,070-pound shells at ships eight miles away. The Army built several other batteries on this end of Santa Rosa Island in the late 1800s and early 1900s.

properties.name: Gator Pond
properties.notes:
Gator Pond https://www.nps.gov/places/000/gator-pond.htm

Do you see or hear any signs of life?

It is a cirlce of life. Gator ponds like this one attract birds, fish, turtles, and frogs that feed on the large numbers of minnows, snails, and aquatic insects. They, in turn, are fed upon by alligators.

Female alligators build a nest of plant debris and mud on the edge of the pond, dig a hole, and lay and bury about 30 eggs that incubate for 60 days before hatching. Their clearing of the vegetation helps keep the water open, and that attracts other animals.

Warning: Never get closer than 15 feet to alligators. Do not feed alligators or any wildlife.

properties.name: Gulf Islands National Seashore Park Headquarters
properties.notes:
Gulf Islands National Seashore Park Headquarters https://www.nps.gov/places/000/guis-headquarters.htm

The Gulf Islands National Seashore park headquarters is located in the Naval Live Oaks Area of the park. The facility is an administrative building only, there are no visitor services inside. 

From this parking lot you can explore outdoor exhibits, water access, and over 7.5 miles of nature trails. Parking, covered pavilions, and a scenic overlook are also avaliable here.

properties.name: High Ground
properties.notes:
High Ground https://www.nps.gov/places/000/high-ground.htm

You are standing on the top of an old sand dune. On the Florida coast a change in elevation of a few feet can make the difference between high, dry ground like this and wet, marshy areas. Here water quickly filters down through the sand. Notice that the types of plant species change as you walk downhill along the trail.

properties.name: Hiking in the Naval Live Oaks Area
properties.notes:
Hiking in the Naval Live Oaks Area https://www.nps.gov/guis/planyourvisit/naval-live-oaks-trails.htm

This is a great spot to start your visit to the bayside of the Naval Live Oaks Area . From this trailhead, you can access most of the trails in the area. Discover the variety of oak and pine woodlands that have taken root on this sandy peninsula between Santa Rosa Sound and Butcherpen Cove. Many small reptiles and mammals live here.

Brackenridge Trail Enjoy exhibits about wildlife, live oaks, and other woodland plants along this 0.8-mile trail.
Andrew Jackson Trail Walk a 2.4-mile section of the Pensacola-St. Augustine Road planned as the first road to connect East and West Florida.
Beaver Pond Trail Hike 1 mile through areas of longleaf pine and oak stands to a beaver pond.Old Borrow Pit Trail. Walk 0.9 mile through longleaf and sand pine communities. Sand from the borrow pit was used in building
U.S. 98. Multi-Use Trail Hike or bike a 2.5-mile section of a paved 40-mile trail along the south side of U.S. 98.

Mileage of Other Trails Fishing 1.2, Boy Scout 0.3, North Bay 0.3, Old Quarry 0.5, Brown's Pond 0.4.

Safety Precautions Wear a hat and sunglasses. Drink plenty of water. Be aware of venomous snakes, insects, and poison ivy. Stay on the trails. Watch children closely. In emergencies call 911.

Park Regulations : Do not disturb or remove any natural, historical, or archeological objects. Metal detectors are prohibited. Do not feed wildlife.

properties.name: Historic Fire Station Restrooms
properties.notes:
Historic Fire Station Restrooms https://www.nps.gov/places/000/fort-pickens-discovery-center-restrooms.htm

Public restrooms are located directly across from the Discovery Center entrance and south of the Fort Pickens Fishing Pier. The building white and green building is a historic Fire Station built in 1940.

properties.name: Historic Life-Saving Station
properties.notes:
Historic Life-Saving Station https://www.nps.gov/places/000/historic-life-saving-station.htm

This building is one of the most iconic buildings in the national seashore. It was orginally constructed in 1885 to serve as the Santa Rosa Island Life-Saving Station. It was one of the two first life-saving stations in all of the state of Florida, and was home to the U.S. Life-Saving Service.

The original structure was a two-story building topped with an enclosed lookout tower that had windows on each side. The keeper, his family, and the crew lived on the second story. In 1907, the current building replaced the destroyed structure.

ith the establishment of the U.S. Coast Guard in 1915, the Santa Rosa Life-Saving Station became Coast Guard Station 212.

In 1986, the U.S. Coast Guard relocated to Naval Air Station Pensacola. The old life-saving station became a part of Gulf Islands National Seashore. Today the building serves as a ranger station and campground registration in the Fort Pickens Area.

properties.name: Horn Island
properties.notes:
Horn Island https://www.nps.gov/places/000/horn-island.htm

Before Horn Island became part of Gulf Islands National Seashore, it was a refuge for Walter Inglis Anderson. Known by the locals as “that crazy artist,” his family called him “Bob.” In the later years of his life, Bob rowed to Horn Island as often as possible. He created thousands of paintings and sketches inspired by the Mississippi island wilderness.
 
Today is it protect as designated Wilderness area. In 1978 Congress designated Horn Island - among the few undeveloped barrier islands on the Gulf Coast - as a Wilderness area. Uncommon species of birds, animals, and marine life are protected here. These areas also preserve the land's natural conditions and provide opportunities for solitude and primitive recreation, benefiting generations to come.

Before visiting Horn Island, ask a ranger about wilderness area regulations and the difficulties of visiting places without water, shelter, facilities, or communication.

properties.name: Hurricane Ivan
properties.notes:
Hurricane Ivan https://www.nps.gov/places/000/hurricane-ivan.htm

On September 16, 2004, Hurricane Ivan roared across the Gulf of Mexico with 130-mile-per-hour winds and struck Santa Rosa Island and the national seashore's Fort Pickens Area nearly head-on. A 14-foot storm surge washed across the island, destroying piers and roads, flooding the fort, and damaging most of the park buildings, including the Discovery Center. Curators, conservators, and other specialists quickly went to work sorting, washing, and preserving over 300,000 cultural artifacts that had been on display or in storage on the island. The Discovery Center was put on new footings in 2007.

properties.name: Langdon Beach Access 16A
properties.notes:
Langdon Beach Access 16A https://www.nps.gov/places/000/langdon-beach-access-16a.htm

This beach access point is located on the Gulf-side within the Fort Pickens Area. It provides access for swimming, fishing, beach-combing and more. Lifeguards are on duty between May and September.

Please stay off of the dunes and out of shorebird enclosures. Camping and overnight parking is not permitted. Pets, glass, and driving are not permitted on beach.

properties.name: Langdon Beach Pavilion
properties.notes:
Langdon Beach Pavilion https://www.nps.gov/places/000/langdon-beach-pavilion.htm

The Langdon Beach pavilion is the only on-beach pavilion in the Fort Pickens Area. Facing the Gulf of Mexico, the pavilion features restrooms, a drinking fountain, and beach showers. The free Fort Pickens Tram Service stops at the pavilion.

properties.name: Life in a Gator Pond
properties.notes:
Life in a Gator Pond https://www.nps.gov/places/000/life-in-a-gator-pond.htm

Gator ponds like this one attract birds, fish, turtles, and frogs that feed on the large numbers of minnows, snails, and aquatic insects. They, in turn, are fed upon by alligators. It's what is known to some as the food chain. If you stand here long enough you are bound to see an alligator. 

Warning. Never get closer than 15 feet to alligators. Do not feed alligators or any wildlife.

properties.name: Life of a Salt Marsh
properties.notes:
Life of a Salt Marsh https://www.nps.gov/places/000/life-of-a-salt-marsh.htm

The salt marsh, despite its starkness, is one of the most productive habitats in the world. Here at high tide, water from the sound flows into the marsh, bringing fresh nutrients, young fish, and larval shrimp and crabs. Plants and animals flourish in this murky mix of salt and fresh water. Spartina and needlerush grow tall, die, and enrich the dark soil. Herons and clapper rails patrol the shallows spearing fish and crabs. At night raccoons and opossums stalk the edges feeding on worms, fish, frogs, and turtles-and watching out for alligators.

properties.name: Massive Smoothbore
properties.notes:
Massive Smoothbore https://www.nps.gov/places/000/massive-smoothbore.htm

A 15-inch Rodman like this gun-one of the largest smoothbore cannons ever developed. It was installed here in 1868, but never fired in combat. Though gradually replaced by rifled, breech-loading artillery, 8, 10, and 15-inch Rodmans remained the primary armament at Fort Pickens and other coastal forts until the late 1880's. The barrel of the 15-inch Rodman weighed 50,000 pounds. With a maximum effective range of three miles, it could fire a 15-inch diameter explosive shell weighing about 300 pounds or a solid 450-pound shot. The circular iron tracks allowed the cannon to be turned to fire in any direction.

properties.name: Nature's Way Trail
properties.notes:
Nature's Way Trail https://www.nps.gov/places/000/nature-s-way-trail.htm This trail is located off of Hanley Road and connects to the Davis Bayou Trail. There are 2 trailheads, both located on Hanley Road. The 0.5 mile loop features views of the bayou and opportunities to view wildlife such as herons and alligators.

There is no parking at either end of the trailhead. Visitors may park and walk to the trail from the campground or visitor center, located on the main park road. 

Duration: 15-30 minutes

properties.name: Naval Live Oaks Area
properties.notes:
Naval Live Oaks Area https://www.nps.gov/places/000/naval-live-oaks-area.htm

Located outside of Gulf Islands National Seashore's headquarters building on the sound-side of the Naval Live Oaks Area, this kiosk provides general information about the seashore and the Naval Live Oaks Area.

Not far from here, is a trailhead for the Brackenridge Accessible Trail that leads to an overlook, and separate path to a picnic area.

This area also features a group campground, small boat launch, and water access to Santa Rosa Sound and Pensacola Bay.

The park headquarters building is not open to the public.

properties.name: Naval Live Oaks Pavilion
properties.notes:
Naval Live Oaks Pavilion https://www.nps.gov/places/000/naval-live-oaks-pavilion.htm

The Naval Live Oaks Area picnic pavilion is located near the park's headquarters building on the north side of Highway 98. The pavilion includes access to picnic tables, charcoal grills, restrooms, and drinking water. The pavilion and picnic tables are on a first come, first served basis, unless prior reservation takes place by a group using the campsite, or another group.

Not far from here are trails that lead to the water of the Santa Rosa Sound. A great place to launch a kayak, fish, or look for wildlife.  

Important: Pets are not permitted under the pavilion or in any facilities. Please dispose of grill materials and waste properly.

properties.name: Naval Live Oaks Picnic Area
properties.notes:
Naval Live Oaks Picnic Area https://www.nps.gov/places/000/naval-live-oaks-picnic-area.htm

The picnic area is located in the Naval Live Oaks Area, offers a great view of the Santa Rosa Sound. This uncovered eating area includes picnic tables and charcoal grills. There are restrooms and drinking water nearby. The picnic tables and grills are on a first come, first served basis.

Not far from here are trails that lead to the shore, a great place to launch a kayak, fish, or look for wildlife.  

Important: Pets are not permitted under the pavilion or in any facilities. Please dispose of grill materials and waste properly.

properties.name: Naval Live Oaks Restrooms
properties.notes:
Naval Live Oaks Restrooms https://www.nps.gov/places/000/naval-live-oaks-restrooms.htm

Restrooms are located near the Naval Live Oaks picnic area and pavilion. In addition to the restrooms, beach showers on the north side of this facility.

properties.name: Naval Live Oaks Small Boat Launch
properties.notes:
Naval Live Oaks Small Boat Launch https://www.nps.gov/places/000/naval-live-oaks-small-boat-launch.htm

Access the calm water of the sound after walking on the tranquil trails in the Naval Live Oaks Area. This is a great place to launch a kayak, canoe, or paddle boat. The launch site is located 60 yards after the sand trail.

properties.name: Naval Live Oaks Youth Campground
properties.notes:
Naval Live Oaks Youth Campground https://www.nps.gov/places/000/naval-live-oaks-youth-campground.htm

The Naval Live Oaks Youth Group campground is available for reservation seasonally by organized groups comprised of youth under the age of 18.


This group camping area has direct access to Pensacola Bay for water recreation and trailheads. It features restrooms, outdoor showers, a picnic shelter, and campfire ring.

properties.name: Nervously Vigilant
properties.notes:
Nervously Vigilant https://www.nps.gov/places/000/nervously-vigilant.htm

The Battery Van Swearingen was built in 1898 for two 4.72-inch Armstrong rifles. It was converted into a range-finding station for Battery Payne in 1922 and used throughout World War II. A U-shaped concrete structure featured two levels: the upper level with two gun emplacements (4.7 inch guns), and the lower level was used to store ammunition and equipment.

properties.name: North Bay Trail
properties.notes:
North Bay Trail https://www.nps.gov/places/north-bay-trail.htm Also known as the Group Camp Trail, the 0.3 mile there-and-back North Bay Trail begins on the Andrew Jackson Trail and follows a sandy path down to the Pensacola Bay.

Duration: 15-30 minutes

properties.name: North South Trail
properties.notes:
North South Trail https://www.nps.gov/places/north-south-trail.htm As the name suggests, this trail runs from the North to South end of Naval Live Oaks. The trail can be started from the end of Reservation Road, but this area is residential and parking is extremely limited. A side trail at the beginning will take visitors down to the Pensacola Bay. If completed as an out-and-back, the trail is 2.2 miles total and takes visitors all the way to Highway 98.

The trail also intersects with the Beaver Pond and Andrew Jackson Trails for visitors wishing to extend their hike.

Duration: 1.5-2 hrs

properties.name: Okaloosa Area
properties.notes:
Okaloosa Area https://www.nps.gov/places/000/okaloosa-area.htm

The Okaloosa Area features an excellent opportunity for access to the calm waters of Choctawhatchee Bay. Located between Fort Walton Beach and Destin, this area is a great place for parasailing, boating, and swimming. There are picnic tables with charcoal grills, restrooms, and beach showers in this area toward the center of the parking lot.

Visitors to this area must have a park pass or pay the fee at the box at the entrance.

Please stay off of the dunes and out of shorebird enclosures. Camping and overnight parking is not permitted. Pets, glass, and driving not permitted on beach.

properties.name: Okaloosa Area Boat Launch
properties.notes:
Okaloosa Area Boat Launch https://www.nps.gov/places/000/okaloosa-area-boat-launch.htm

The Okaloosa Area features an excellent opportunity for access to the calm waters of Choctawhatchee Bay. Located between Fort Walton Beach and Destin, this area is a great place to picnic, boat, and swim. 

The boat launch is the perfect place to launch a kayak, canoe, or paddleboard. Trailer launching is not recommended.

properties.name: Okaloosa Area Orientation Kiosk
properties.notes:
Okaloosa Area Orientation Kiosk https://www.nps.gov/places/000/okaloosa-area-orientation-kiosk.htm

The Okaloosa Area Orientation Kiosk is centrally located near the restrooms. Here visitors can learn about the national seashore, beach safety, and the park's interpretive themes.

properties.name: Okaloosa Area Restrooms
properties.notes:
Okaloosa Area Restrooms https://www.nps.gov/places/000/okaloosa-area-restrooms.htm

The Okaloosa Area features a restroom facility with beach showers.

properties.name: Old Borrow Pit Trail
properties.notes:
Old Borrow Pit Trail https://www.nps.gov/places/old-borrow-pit-trail.htm

If completed round-trip, the Old Borrow Pit Trail is 1.8 miles total. This there-and-back trail begins at a trailhead behind residential property at Reservation Road and leads to Highway 98. There is no parking available at the trailhead as the area is residential, but visitors may park at the dirt pulloff further down Reservation Road.

Sand from the borrow pit was used for the construction of U. S. Highway 98. The trail is sandy with little shade, so be sure to bring appropriate footwear and water. It also intersects with the Old Quarry, Beaver Pond, and Andrew Jackson Trails for visitors wishing to extend their hike.

Duration: 1-1.5 hours

properties.name: Old Quarry Trail
properties.notes:
Old Quarry Trail https://www.nps.gov/places/old-quarry-trail.htm

The Old Quarry Trail begins from the trailhead on Bayshore Boulevard where limited roadside parking is available. This is a 1.7-mile out-and-back trail that ends where it joins the North-South Trail. You will find several other main trails that connect to the Quarry trail for visitors who wish to extend their hike, including the Old Borrow Pit Trail, Brown's Pond Trail, and North South Trail. There is also a small loop available almost immediately after the trail begins.

The trail is sandy with little shade, so be sure to bring water and appropriate footwear.

Duration: 45-90 minutes

properties.name: Opal Beach Area
properties.notes:
Opal Beach Area https://www.nps.gov/places/000/opal-beach-area.htm

Gulf Islands National Seashore protects historical heritage and ever-changing features of the Gulf Coast-salt marshes, marine woodlands, sparkling white beaches, and coastal waters. The seashore includes several islands and portions of the mainland. 

The Opal Beach Complex is located along Highway 399 between Pensacola Beach and Navarre Beach, provides access to one of the park's greatest treasures, Opal Beach. This is a great place to fish, swim, and picnic. Parking, restrooms, pavilions, and beach showers are available both Gulf-side and sound-side.

Visitors must pay an entrance fee or display a park pass to use this area. Passes are good for seven days and can be purchased at the park entrance stations or online. For more frequent visitors, the national seashore offers an annual pass providing 12-months of unlimited entries into all of the park's areas.

properties.name: Opal Beach Cluster A
properties.notes:
Opal Beach Cluster A https://www.nps.gov/places/000/opal-beach-cluster-a.htm

Enjoy the white sands and emerald green waters of the gulf or the calm waters of the sound. The Opal Beach Complex located in the Santa Rosa Area of Gulf Islands National Seashore is a great place to boat, fish, and swim.

Cluster A is the western-most cluster of pavilions on the Gulf-side of the Opal Beach Complex. This is one of four pavilions in the complex that can be reserved by visiting the permits page. 

Lifeguards are on duty in this area May through September. Please stay off of the dunes and out of shorebird enclosures. Camping and overnight parking is not permitted. Pets, glass, and driving not permitted on the beach.

properties.name: Opal Beach Cluster B1
properties.notes:
Opal Beach Cluster B1 https://www.nps.gov/places/000/opal-beach-cluster-b1.htm

Enjoy the white sands and emerald green waters of the gulf or the calm waters of the sound. The Opal Beach Complex located in the Santa Rosa Area of Gulf Islands National Seashore is a great place to boat, fish, and swim.

Cluster B1 is a cluster of pavilions on the Gulf-side of the Opal Beach Complex. This is one of four pavilions in the complex that can be reserved by visiting the permits page. 

Lifeguards are on duty in this area May through September. Please stay off of the dunes and out of shorebird enclosures. Camping and overnight parking is not permitted. Pets, glass, and driving not permitted on the beach.

properties.name: Opal Beach Cluster B2
properties.notes:
Opal Beach Cluster B2 https://www.nps.gov/places/000/opal-beach-cluster-b2.htm

Enjoy the white sands and emerald green waters of the gulf or the calm waters of the sound. The Opal Beach Complex located in the Santa Rosa Area of Gulf Islands National Seashore is a great place to boat, fish, and swim.


Cluster B2 is a cluster of pavilions on the Gulf-side of the Opal Beach Complex. This is one of four pavilions in the complex that can be reserved by visiting the permits page. 

Lifeguards are on duty in this area May through September. Please stay off of the dunes and out of shorebird enclosures. Camping and overnight parking is not permitted. Pets, glass, and driving not permitted on the beach.

properties.name: Opal Beach Cluster C
properties.notes:
Opal Beach Cluster C https://www.nps.gov/places/000/opal-beach-cluster-c.htm

Enjoy the white sands and emerald green waters of the gulf or the calm waters of the sound. The Opal Beach Complex located in the Santa Rosa Area of Gulf Islands National Seashore is a great place to boat, fish, and swim.

Cluster C is the only cluster of pavilions on the sound-side of the Opal Beach Complex. The area also has facilities including restrooms, pavilion, water fountains, and outdoors showers. Lifeguards are on duty in this area May through September.

Please stay off of the dunes and out of shorebird enclosures. Camping and overnight parking is not permitted. Pets, glass, and driving not permitted on the beach.

properties.name: Opal Beach Cluster D
properties.notes:
Opal Beach Cluster D https://www.nps.gov/places/000/opal-beach-cluster-d.htm

Enjoy the white sands and emerald green waters of the gulf or the calm waters of the sound. The Opal Beach Complex located in the Santa Rosa Area of Gulf Islands National Seashore is a great place to boat, fish, and swim.

Cluster D is the central cluster of pavilions on the Gulf-side of the Opal Beach Complex. The area also has facilities including restrooms, pavilion, water fountains, and outdoors showers. Lifeguards are on duty in this area May through September.

Please stay off of the dunes and out of shorebird enclosures. Camping and overnight parking is not permitted. Pets, glass, and driving not permitted on the beach.

properties.name: Opal Beach Cluster E
properties.notes:
Opal Beach Cluster E https://www.nps.gov/places/000/opal-beach-cluster-e.htm

Enjoy the white sands and emerald green waters of the gulf or the calm waters of the sound. The Opal Beach Complex located in the Santa Rosa Area of Gulf Islands National Seashore is a great place to boat, fish, and swim.

Cluster E is the eastern-most cluster of pavilions on the Gulf-side of the Opal Beach Complex. Lifeguards are on duty in this area May through September.

lease stay off of the dunes and out of shorebird enclosures. Camping and overnight parking is not permitted. Pets, glass, and driving not permitted on beach.

properties.name: Pensacola Bay City Ferry: Downtown Pensacola Departure Point
properties.notes:
Pensacola Bay City Ferry: Downtown Pensacola Departure Point https://www.nps.gov/places/000/pensacola-bay-city-ferry-downtown-pensacola-departure-point.htm

Pensacola Bay City Ferry tour boats link downtown Pensacola, Pensacola Beach, and the Fort Pickens Area of Gulf Islands National Seashore seasonally. While onboard the vessels visitors will enjoy beautiful views of the coastline and historic structures. The ride is about 45 minutes between each departure point location. 

The City of Pensacola is one of America's oldest settlements, built on 450 years of European-influenced history and architecture. The city celebrates a diversity of culture, customs, and geography in its parks, plazas, and old oak-lined streets. Downtown features 40 square blocks of museums, monuments, cultural centers, and gardens. Visitors enjoy the rich and evolving arts scene, and the local charm and flavor of Pensacola's restaurants, main street shops, and seasonal festivals.

HMS Ferries, Inc., operating as Pensacola Bay City Ferry, a private, nonsubsidized, for-profit company has signed a concessions contract to operate the service.

properties.name: Pensacola Bay City Ferry: Fort Pickens Departure Point
properties.notes:
Pensacola Bay City Ferry: Fort Pickens Departure Point https://www.nps.gov/places/000/pensacola-bay-city-ferry-fort-pickens-departure-point.htm

Pensacola Bay City Ferry tour boats link downtown Pensacola, Pensacola Beach, and the Fort Pickens Area of Gulf Islands National Seashore seasonally. While onboard the vessels visitors will enjoy beautiful views of the coastline and historic structures. The ride is about 45 minutes between each departure point location. 

Fort Pickens is a historic U.S. Army fort on Santa Rosa Island in the Pensacola area. The fort is the largest of four forts built to defend Pensacola Bay and its navy yard from foreign powers.

HMS Ferries, Inc., operating as Pensacola Bay City Ferry, a private, nonsubsidized, for-profit company has signed a concessions contract to operate the service.

properties.name: Pensacola Bay City Ferry: Pensacola Beach Departure Point
properties.notes:
Pensacola Bay City Ferry: Pensacola Beach Departure Point https://www.nps.gov/places/000/pensacola-bay-city-ferry-pensacola-beach-departure-point.htm

Pensacola Bay City Ferry tour boats link downtown Pensacola, Pensacola Beach, and the Fort Pickens Area of Gulf Islands National Seashore seasonally. Whionboardard the vessels visitors will enjoy beautiful views of the coastline and historic structures. The ride is about 45 minutes between each departure point location. 

No matter what the season, beachgoers can relax on the sunny, peaceful shores of the Pensacola Beach area's emerald-green coastline. Pensacola Beach also offers an array of shopping, lodging, restaurants, and entertainment.

HMS Ferries, Inc., operating as Pensacola Bay City Ferry, a private, nonsubsidized, for-profit company has signed a concessions contract to operate the service.

properties.name: Perdido Key Area
properties.notes:
Perdido Key Area https://www.nps.gov/places/000/perdido-key-area.htm

Welcome to the Perdido Key Area! This area features access to the white-sand beaches and blue-green waters of the Gulf of Mexico. Visitors can also enjoy bird watching along this accessible Perdido Key Discovery Trail or launch a kayak at the small boat launch area. Discover history behind Rosamond Johnson Beach and memorial. Restrooms, showers, parking, and picnic shelters are available at Rosamond Johnson Beach.

properties.name: Perdido Key Area Entrance Station
properties.notes:
Perdido Key Area Entrance Station https://www.nps.gov/places/000/perdido-key-area-entrance-station.htm

Visit the Perdido Key Area of Gulf Islands National Seashore. This area features historic structures, a memorial, trails, covered pavilions with picnic tables, and access to one of most popular attractions, Johnson Beach. Lifeguards are on duty Memorial Day through Labor Day. 

This area only has one entrance station and is very busy in the peak season (March - October). Traffic information is featured on digital signs prior to the entrance station. 

Entrance fees are charged at this Florida location of the national seashore. Passes are good for seven days and can be purchased at the park entrance stations or online. For more frequent visitors, the national seashore offers an annual pass providing 12-months of unlimited entries into all of the park's areas.

properties.name: Perdido Key Discovery Trail
properties.notes:
Perdido Key Discovery Trail https://www.nps.gov/places/000/perdido-key-discovery-trail.htm

Note: This trail is currently closed to the public due to sustained hurricane damage. We apologize for the inconvenience.

Walk along this boardwalk loop in the Perdido Key area and discover a variety of habitats, including a salt marsh, wooded wetland, and sand dunes. From herons to woodpeckers, raccoons to otters, and frogs to snakes, these barrier island habitats attract a diversity of birds, small mammals, and reptiles. Take your time, look high and low, and listen carefully.

The 0.36 mile accessible trail loops back to Johnson Beach Road about 0.1 mile away. Visitors may park across the street at Johnson Beach Road parking and cross over to access the trail.

Trailhead locations:

  • North loop - near Johnson Beach ramp/boat launch
  • South loop - first left on Johnson Beach Road

Duration: 15-30 minutes

properties.name: Perdido Key Discovery Trail - North Trailhead
properties.notes:
Perdido Key Discovery Trail - North Trailhead https://www.nps.gov/places/000/perdido-key-discovery-north-trailhead.htm

Note: This trail is currently closed to the public due to sustained hurricane damage. We apologize for the inconvenience.

Walk along this boardwalk loop in the Perdido Key area and discover a variety of habitats, including a salt marsh, wooded wetland, and sand dunes. From herons to woodpeckers, raccoons to otters, and frogs to snakes, these barrier island habitats attract a diversity of birds, small mammals, and reptiles. Take your time, look high and low, and listen carefully.

The 0.36 mile accessible trail loops back to Johnson Beach Road about 0.1 mile away. Visitors may park across the street at Johnson Beach Road parking and cross over to access the trail.

Trailhead locations:

  • North loop - near Johnson Beach ramp/boat launch
  • South loop - first left on Johnson Beach Road

properties.name: Perdido Key Small Boat Launch
properties.notes:
Perdido Key Small Boat Launch https://www.nps.gov/places/000/perdido-key-small-boat-launch.htm

Lauch your kayak or paddleboard here for access to historical points of interest, extensive seagrass beds, and interesting wildlife. This small boat launch is the trail-head for the Perdido Key Blueway. This Perdido Key Blueway comprises the first 5.5 mile portion of the 1,515 mile Florida Circumnavigational Saltwater Paddling Trail. 

This launch is not suitable for trailer boat launching. Parking is limited at this launch, you may need to unload and then park in the larger Rosamond Johnson Beach parking lots.

Do not enter historic military ruins near the site of Fort McRee or remove any historic artifacts on land or in the water.

properties.name: Petit Bois Island
properties.notes:
Petit Bois Island https://www.nps.gov/places/000/petit-bois-island.htm

A great place to see fish, bird watch, or camp on an undistrubed beach, this island is only accessible by boat. Petit Bois Island is a barrier island located off the coast of Mississippi, Southeast of Davis Bayou. The island is designated a wilderness area which provides protection for plants and animals to thrive undisturbed.

Petit Bois Island is shrinking. In order to preserve it, the U.S. Army Corp of Engineers dredged sand from the island's shipping channel to create a new island, called West Petit Bois Island. As West Petit Bois Island continues to grow, plant and animal life are finding its way to the island. The impermanence and ever-changing environments of barrier islands are what make them so unique.   

Before visiting Petit Bois Island , ask a ranger about wilderness area regulations and the difficulties of visiting places without water, shelter, facilities, or communication.

properties.name: Pine Scrub Loop
properties.notes:
Pine Scrub Loop https://www.nps.gov/places/pine-scrub-loop.htm

This 0.5 mile trail will take you down to the Pensacola Bay, where you may sit and look out on the water before turning around and continuing the loop. The trail both starts on the Andrew Jackson Trail, and is found adjacent to the North Bay (Group Camp) Trail.

Duration: 15-30 minutes

properties.name: Primary Dunes-1
properties.notes:
Primary Dunes-1 https://www.nps.gov/places/000/primary-dunes-1.htm

Looking towards the Gulf of Mexico, woody plants are replaced by sea oats, also known as the local dune grass. Closer to the gulf, a plant is exposed to more environmental stresses. These conditions with which living plants must content are wind-carried salt particles, sand shifted by water and winds, differing amounts of nutrients in the soil, the drying effect of wind and sometimes being overwashed by the sea itself.

properties.name: Restoring a Fort
properties.notes:
Restoring a Fort https://www.nps.gov/places/000/restoring-a-fort.htm

Fort Barrancas and the Spanish Water Battery deteriorated after the U.S. Army closed its base here in 1947. A hard freeze in 1950 caused the parapet of the water battery's rifle gallery to collapse, and plants overgrew the structure. Debris filled Fort Barrancas tunnels and passageways. When the fort and battery became part of Gulf Islands National Seashore, the National Park Service obtained funds to restore them, and staff historians conducted extensive research. Using 90,000 new bricks, masons repaired the brickwork. Carpenters rebuilt doors, gates, and a drawbridge. The fort was opened to the public in 1980.

properties.name: Rosamond Johnson Beach
properties.notes:
Rosamond Johnson Beach https://www.nps.gov/places/000/rosamond-johnson-beach.htm

Visit Rosamond Johnson Beach for access to the pristine emerald coast waters of the Gulf of Mexico. Great for water activities, beach combing, and most popular as a swim beach. During the summer months (May to September), lifeguards are on duty and fishing is not permitted within the flagged swim beach.

Two large parking lots provide convenient access to the beach, picnic pavilions, restrooms, water fountains, and beach showers.

Please stay off of the dunes and out of shorebird enclosures. Pets, glass, and driving are not permitted on the beach. Overnight parking is not permitted.

Traffic does back up at this location and is monitored. Traffic updates can be found on the digital reader boards before reaching the entrance stations.

properties.name: Rosamond Johnson Beach East Pavilion
properties.notes:
Rosamond Johnson Beach East Pavilion https://www.nps.gov/places/000/rosamond-johnson-beach-east-pavilion.htm

This picnic pavilion is located on the eastern end of Rosamond Johnson Beach overlooking the beach and the Gulf of Mexico. A ramp leads up to the pavilion from the parking lot. There are accessible restrooms, drinking fountains, beach showers, and grills located immediately adjacent to the pavilion.

properties.name: Rosamond Johnson Beach West Pavilion
properties.notes:
Rosamond Johnson Beach West Pavilion https://www.nps.gov/places/000/rosamond-johnson-beach-west-pavilion.htm

This picnic pavilion is located on the western end of Rosamond Johnson Beach overlooking the beach and the Gulf of Mexico. A ramp leads up to the pavilion from the parking lot. There are accessible restrooms, drinking fountains, beach showers, and grills located immediately adjacent to the pavilion

properties.name: Rosamond Johnson Memorial
properties.notes:
Rosamond Johnson Memorial https://www.nps.gov/places/000/rosamond-johnson-memorial.htm

This memorial was established by the National Park Service to recognize the service and sacrifice of the beach's namesake, U.S. Army Private Rosamond Johnson. He was killed in action during the Korean War.

The memorial features a plaque, flag pole, and two interpretive exhibits. While places like Pensacola Beach were designated “whites only”, the eastern end of Perdido Key became a refuge where black citizens could enjoy the beauty and recreational opportunities of the beach and the Gulf. The exhibits illustrate the inequities of access to public beaches by people of color and the service of Johnson.

properties.name: Rugged Casemates
properties.notes:
Rugged Casemates https://www.nps.gov/places/000/rugged-casemates.htm

You are standing in one of the fort's 21 gun chambers known as casemates. Thirteen casemates on this level housed 10-inch Rodman cannon in the 1860s, but they were never fired in combat. Notice the arched ceiling, which was designed to transfer the massive weight of the brick and cannon above to the vertical piers and to withstand the shock waves from cannon when fired. Between firings the gun crew could close the embrasure-the opening in the wall-with iron shutters to protect themselves from enemy fire.

properties.name: Rustling Creatures
properties.notes:
Rustling Creatures https://www.nps.gov/places/000/rustling-creatures.htm

Listen carefully for the rustle of leaf litter on the forest floor or at night, for a chorus of barking tree frogs. You may hear skinks and salamanders foraging for insects in the leaves beneath saw palmettos, sweet bay, and other plants. Early in the day or after a rain, listen for box turtles plodding along looking for earthworms, berries, and mushrooms. Barely audible as they slither their way through the underbrush, snakes hunt for frogs, lizards, and mice.

properties.name: Safer than Brick
properties.notes:
Safer than Brick https://www.nps.gov/places/000/safer-than-brick.htm

Walk to the top of this earthen mound to see Battery Trueman's concrete walls and a scenic view of the harbor entrance. Fort Pickens' brick walls and cast-iron guns had become obsolete by the end of the Civil War. Harbor defenses now called for steel guns in low-lying concrete batteries.

Trueman's 3-inch, rapid-fire guns, mounted in 1905, guarded the inner channel and minefield against fast torpedo boats and minesweepers, the latest threats of the day. From the water Battery Trueman's 3-inch rifles did not appear very threatening, but they could fire up to 10 rounds a minute. Trueman's guns and equipment were moved to Battery Cullum in 1943.

properties.name: Santa Rosa Area Entrance Sign
properties.notes:
Santa Rosa Area Entrance Sign https://www.nps.gov/places/000/santa-rosa-area-entrance-sign.htm

Welcome to the Santa Rosa Area! This area features access to the white-sand beaches and blue-green waters of the Gulf of Mexico. Visitors can continue to hike on the Florida National Scenic Trail along the beach or enjoy the scenery from a boardwalk trail. Restrooms, showers, parking, and picnic shelters are available at the Opal Beach Complex.

properties.name: Secondary Dunes
properties.notes:
Secondary Dunes https://www.nps.gov/places/000/secondary-dunes.htm

Santa Rosa Island is 43 miles long, and here about two and a half miles from the west end of the island, you find the widest section. You will also see a well-developed maritime forest of slash pine, live oak and other species commonly found on the mainland.

properties.name: Ship Island Entrance Sign
properties.notes:
Ship Island Entrance Sign https://www.nps.gov/places/000/ship-island-entrance-sign.htm

Welcome to Ship Island ! Explore historic Fort Massachusetts, have a picnic, go for a hike, swim in the Gulf of Mexico, spot wildlife, or just sit back and enjoy the salt air on the beach.

properties.name: Ship Island Excursions: Gulfport Departure Point
properties.notes:
Ship Island Excursions: Gulfport Departure Point https://www.nps.gov/places/000/ship-island-excursions-gulfport-departure-point.htm

Catch a ferry to Ship Island with Ship Island Excursions. Ship Island Excursions provides public ferry service from Biloxi and Gulfport to Gulf Islands National Seashore's Ship Island between mid-March and October each year.

Ship Island is one of the most popular of Coastal Mississippi’s six barrier islands. Located approximately 11 miles south of Gulfport and Biloxi, its beautiful beaches are a part of the Gulf Islands National Seashore.

Arriving on the north shore of the island, you’ll witness the beautifully preserved Fort Massachusetts, a brick fortification completed in 1868. With a strategic deep-water harbor located near the island, Ship Island was used in battle as far back as the War of 1812. Rangers and volunteers lead free guided tours for those interested in learning more about its incredible history.

The north shore also features a boardwalk that extends to the more-popular south shore of the island, where you’ll find beautiful beaches, pristine waters, public restrooms, and a snack bar.

properties.name: Ship Island Lighthouses
properties.notes:
Ship Island Lighthouses https://www.nps.gov/places/000/ship-island-lighthouses.htm

The first lighthouse was completed in 1853 and survived the fighting at Ship Island during the Civil War. Eventually, the harsh environment took its toll on the lighthouse and it was abandoned in 1885. A new lighthouse was constructed in 1886. For nearly a century this lighthouse signaled the safety of Mississippi Sound until 1957. After surviving numerous storms and strong hurricanes, the wooden tower was accidentally set on fire by campers and destroyed in 1972.

Area residents mourned the loss of the historic structure a proposal was initiated and approved to build a replica-styled exhibit. Construction of the new exhibit started in 1998 and was capped off when a Coast Guard helicopter placed the new cupola a top the tower in February 2000. Unfortunately, Hurricane Katrina’s intense winds and waves destroyed the exhibit just five years after its dedication.

properties.name: Ship Island Pier
properties.notes:
Ship Island Pier https://www.nps.gov/places/000/ship-island-tour-boat-pier.htm

Catch a ferry to Ship Island with Ship Island Excursions. This pier is located on Ship Island, and can take visitors to Biloxi or Gulfport.

Ship Island is one of the most popular of Coastal Mississippi’s six barrier islands. Located approximately 11 miles south of Gulfport and Biloxi, its beautiful beaches are a part of the Gulf Islands National Seashore.

Arriving on the north shore of the island, you’ll witness the beautifully preserved Fort Massachusetts, a brick fortification completed in 1868. With a strategic deep-water harbor located near the island, Ship Island was used in battle as far back as the War of 1812. Rangers and volunteers lead free guided tours for those interested in learning more about its incredible history.

The north shore also features a boardwalk that extends to the more-popular south shore of the island, where you’ll find beautiful beaches, pristine waters, public restrooms, and a snack bar.

A portion of the pier is open to loading and unloading from private vessels, look for signs on the pier to direct you to the appropriate locations. Private vessels may not be left unattended at the pier.

properties.name: Ship Island Swim Beach
properties.notes:
Ship Island Swim Beach https://www.nps.gov/places/000/ship-island-swim-beach.htm

The Ship Island swim beach is located on the southside of the island and provides access for swimming, wading, fishing, beach-combing and more.

There are restrooms, beach showers, water fountains, a pavilion, and concession stand located nearby. This beach is accessable by private boat. Lifeguards are on duty during the summer months.

properties.name: Shoot and Duck
properties.notes:
Shoot and Duck https://www.nps.gov/places/000/shoot-and-duck.htm

Battery Cooper's rifles popped up, disappeared, and reappeared like a jack-in-the-box. The battery, built in 1906, had two 6-inch rifles mounted on disappearing carriages.
