When the guns were fired, the recoil automatically lowered them behind the concrete wall, which protected the crews while they reloaded the guns. Counterweights returned them to the firing position. During World War I, the US Army removed the guns for possible use as railway guns in France. The gun you see here today came from the Smithsonian Institution.

properties.name: Standing Tall
properties.notes:
Standing Tall https://www.nps.gov/places/000/standing-tall.htm

Oaks, magnolias, and hickory trees have withstood strong winds and salt spray to produce a dense forest canopy in this old dune area between Santa Rosa Sound and Pensacola Bay. Other trees that have taken root in the sandy soil include redbays, laurel oaks, eastern red cedars, and slash pines. Growing beneath them are yaupon holly, saw palmetto, and-in the wet peaty swales-sawgrass. The gray garlands hanging from live oaks are Spanish moss. Not a true moss but a member of the pineapple family, it absorbs water and food from the air. This mixed woodland serves both as a wildlife habitat and as a storm buffer for the mainland.

properties.name: Stark Bayou Overlook
properties.notes:
Stark Bayou Overlook https://www.nps.gov/places/000/stark-bayou-overlook.htm

The Stark Bayou overlooks an open marsh full of vegetation and winding waterways, all bordered by a woodland area. A boardwalk stretching across the bayou makes this is a great place to view wildlife or take photographs. Often this waterway is one of the best places to see wildlife like birds, turtles, crabs, and alligators. 

Parking is available at the beginning of the waterway in front of the Nature’s Way Loop Trail entrance, or just past the waterway across at the corner of Robert MeGhee Road and Boat Launch. Please do not stop your vehicle in the road for a photo, as this can be dangerous to other cars, people, and wildlife.

properties.name: Step Back in History
properties.notes:
Step Back in History https://www.nps.gov/places/000/step-back-in-history.htm

Step back in history for a glance of Fort Pickens. To learn more about the fascinating history of this defensive fortification, follow the sidewalk straight ahead and begin your self-guiding tour.

properties.name: Storm Buffers & Murky Birthplace
properties.notes:
Storm Buffers & Murky Birthplace https://www.nps.gov/places/000/storm-buffers-murky-birthplace.htm

Storm Buffers
In front of you, beyond Davis Bayou and Deer Island, are some storm buffers. Though 8 to 10 miles away, Horn Island and five other islands-Petit Bois, West Petit Bois, Ship, and Cat- help shield the sound and the mainland from the full brunt of hurricane winds and waves stoked by the gulf's warm waters. These islands slowly migrate westward as they are reshaped by currents running along the shorelines. They are part of an irregular 2,000-mile chain of barrier islands along the U.S. coast from New York to Texas.

Vegetation plays a critical role in shaping the landforms and providing some stability. On the islands, grasses trap sands that form dunes, where shrubs and trees take root. Seagrass beds and salt marshes help curb erosion.

Murky Birthplace
Don't let the stillness of the salt marsh fool you. The dark murky waters are swimming and crawling with life. Protected from predators of the open sea, the marsh serves as a productive breeding ground, maternity ward, and nursery for shrimp, crabs, shellfish, and finfish. Juvenile clams, oysters, and mussels filter nutrients from the tides. Young fiddler crabs and blue crabs feed on decaying plants and tiny organisms in the mud. Croaker, redfish, and mullet minnows devour aquatic insects, grow up, and as adults move out to the open coastal waters.

properties.name: Teeming with Life - Brackenridge Trail
properties.notes:
Teeming with Life - Brackenridge Trail https://www.nps.gov/places/000/teeming-with-life-brackenridge-trail.htm

From the forest floor to the treetops, this coastal woodland is full of activity. Beneath the live oaks, magnolias, and saw palmettos, frogs, skinks, snakes, and salamanders forage for bugs and beetles in the leaf litter and on downed trees. Armadillos, skunks, and raccoons shuffle along feeding on ants, worms, spiders, and berries. Squirrels dart here and there gathering acorns and nuts to feed their young high up in the oak and hickory trees. Vireos, warblers, and woodpeckers fill the air with calls and songs.

properties.name: The Mine Storeroom
properties.notes:
The Mine Storeroom https://www.nps.gov/places/000/the-mine-storeroom.htm

In the Mine Storeroom, visitors can learn about the historic use of the building by the U.S. Army. It was originally built in 1898 to hide the mine defense system. After an explosion at Fort Pickens in 1899, the structure was rebuilt on the existing foundation.  The Army eliminated Pensacola’s mine defense system in 1926. Afterward, the responsibility for the harbor’s mine system fell to the U.S. Navy. The Army repurposed each structure for other purposes and continued using them through World War II.

Today the storeroom is operated by the park's tour boat concessioner, Pensacola Bay Cruises, and is open when the tour boats are running. Visitors can purchase tour boat tickets, food, and beverages inside. Outside the building there are additional exhibits, a water filling station, a shade shelter, and restroom facilities. In between the buildings, a wide sidewalk leads to the pier where the ferry docks.

properties.name: Trench Trail
properties.notes:
Trench Trail https://www.nps.gov/places/000/fort-barrancas-trench-visitor-center-trailhead.htm

This trail begins adjacent to the Fort Barrancas Visitor Center. Visitors may park next to the visitor center and begin the trail, which crosses the road and connects to Advanced Redoubt. Portions of the historic communication trench are visible all along the trail.
Use extreme caution crossing the busy highway. Bicycles are not permitted. The trail is 0.5 miles total.

Trailhead locations: 

  • Fort Barrancas Visitor Center
  • Advanced Redoubt

Duration: 30-45 minutes

Note: This trail is inside Naval Air Station Pensacola, which is currently closed to the public. Visitors must have an eligible DoD ID to access the base and the Fort Barrancas area. We apologize for the inconvenience.

properties.name: Trench Trail - Advanced Redoubt Trailhead
properties.notes:
Trench Trail - Advanced Redoubt Trailhead https://www.nps.gov/places/000/fort-barrancas-trench-advanced-redoubt-trailhead.htm

This trail begins in the southeast corner of the Advanced Redoubt parkling lot. Visitors may park at Advanced Redoubt and begin the trail, which crosses the road and connects to Fort Barrancas and the visitor center. Portions of the historic communication trench are visible all along the trail.
Use extreme caution crossing the busy highway. Bicycles are not permitted. The trail is 0.5 miles total.

Trailhead locations: 

  • Fort Barrancas Visitor Center
  • Advanced Redoubt

Note: This trail is inside Naval Air Station Pensacola, which is currently closed to the public. Visitors must have a military or federal ID to access the base and the Fort Barrancas area. We apologize for the inconvenience.

properties.name: West Petit Bois Island
properties.notes:
West Petit Bois Island https://www.nps.gov/places/000/west-petit-bois-island.htm

A great place to see fish, bird watch, or camp on an undistrubed beach, this island is only accessible by boat. West Petit Bois Island is a barrier island located off the coast of Mississippi, Southeast of Davis Bayou. The island is designated a wilderness area which provides protection for plants and animals to thrive undisturbed.

Petit Bois Island is shrinking. In order to preserve it, the U.S. Army Corp of Engineers dredged sand from the island's shipping channel to create a new island, called West Petit Bois Island. As West Petit Bois Island continues to grow, plant and animal life are finding its way to the island. The impermanence and ever-changing environments of barrier islands are what make them so unique.

properties.name: Wildlife Signatures
properties.notes:
Wildlife Signatures https://www.nps.gov/places/000/wildlife-signatures.htm

Think of this area as a woodland pantry full of insects, reptiles, bird eggs, and carrion that attract a variety of small mammals. Squirrels, otters, armadillos, and mice usually search for food during daylight. Raccoons, skunks, foxes, and opossums commonly rest during the day and forage at night. You may not see them, but look for footprints, scat, nibbled bark, and other signs of their presence.

properties.name: William M. Colmer Visitor Center
properties.notes:
William M. Colmer Visitor Center https://www.nps.gov/places/000/william-m-colmer-visitor-center.htm

A great place to start your visit to the Davis Bayou Area or the Mississippi islands. Explore indoor exhibits, watch a video about the history of the entire Gulf Islands National Seashore, or view wildlife in person from the observation deck located outside the building.

properties.name: Woodland Nature Trail
properties.notes:
Woodland Nature Trail https://www.nps.gov/places/000/fort-barrancas-woodland-nature-trailhead.htm

This trail is a 0.25 mile loop that begins and ends at the Fort Barrancas Visitor Center. Visitors may park at the visitor center and begin the trail to the west. The dirt path is fairly smooth with a sandy base, but can be slippery when wet. Use caution and respect wildlife on the trail. 

Succession in natural communities is the process by which new species of plants and animals become established as conditions change. As trees grow tall in coastal woodlands, they shade out sun-loving plants on the forest floor. Sometimes change occurs rapidly. Winds generated by tropical storms knock down mature trees and strip the leaves from others. This permits sunlight to reach the forest floor again and allows the return of wildflowers, grasses, and mosses.

Duration: 15-30 minutes

Note: This trail is inside Naval Air Station Pensacola, which is currently closed to the public. Visitors must have a military or federal ID to access the base and the Fort Barrancas area. We apologize for the inconvenience.
